plant.description: A woody vine known as American Bittersweet, producing orange-yellow berries. All parts are toxic.

toxins.name: Solanine (specifically classified as a glycoalkaloid). Related alkaloids such as solasodine or tomatine may also be present depending on the specific
toxins.description:
in cats:
    ◦ Acetylcholinesterase Inhibition: Solanine inhibits the enzyme acetylcholinesterase, which breaks down the neurotransmitter acetylcholine. This leads to an accumulation of acetylcholine and overstimulation of the parasympathetic nervous system, causing neurological symptoms like tremors, ataxia (loss of coordination), and seizures.
    ◦ Cytotoxicity: The compound interacts with cell membranes (phospholipids), increasing their permeability and causing cell destruction (cytolysis). This is particularly damaging to the intestinal lining, leading to severe gastrointestinal irritation, inflammation, and hemorrhage.
    ◦ Mitochondrial Impairment: It disrupts cellular energy balance by inhibiting the respiratory chain.
toxins.concentration_notes: ◦ Potency: The sources describe Nightshade plants, including bittersweet, as "extremely toxic" to cats.

symptoms.name: Vomiting, Diarrhea, and Hypersalivation (Drooling)
symptoms.notes: These are often the first signs of poisoning. The plant contains solanine, which is a severe irritant to the gastrointestinal tract and mucous membranes.Neurological Depression

symptoms.name: Drowsiness, Depression, Confusion, and Weakness
symptoms.onset: 2–24 hours (typically follows or accompanies GI signs).
symptoms.notes: The toxins affect the central nervous system, leading to significant lethargy and behavioral changes. In severe cases, this can progress to paralysis or coma.Ocular Abnormalities

symptoms.name: Dilated Pupils (Mydriasis)
symptoms.notes: Dilated pupils are a hallmark neurological sign of toxicity from plants in the Nightshade family.Bradycardia

symptoms.name: Slow Heart Rate (Bradycardia)
symptoms.notes: The toxins can disrupt heart rhythm, leading to a dangerously slow heartbeat, which contributes to the classification of this plant as "extremely toxic."

treatments.name: Induction of Emesis (Vomiting) or Gastric Lavage
treatments.description: If the ingestion was recent (typically within 1–2 hours) and the cat is not showing severe symptoms, the veterinarian may induce vomiting using medication (such as xylazine for cats) to remove the plant material from the stomach. Alternatively, gastric lavage (stomach pumping) may be performed under anesthesia to wash out the stomach contents.
treatments.notes: This is the primary defense to prevent further toxin absorption. It is only performed if the ingestion is recent and the cat is neurologically stable. Self-medication or inducing vomiting at home is not recommended; immediate veterinary intervention is required.Toxin Adsorption

treatments.name: Activated Charcoal Administration
treatments.description: The administration of medical-grade activated charcoal (1–4 g/kg body weight) into the digestive tract. This substance binds to the unabsorbed solanine toxins in the gut, preventing them from entering the bloodstream.
treatments.notes: In severe poisoning cases, administration may need to be repeated multiple times at 4 to 6-hour intervals because solanine can undergo "enterohepatic recirculation" (reabsorption by the body).Fluid Therapy

treatments.name: Intravenous (IV) Fluid Therapy
treatments.description: The administration of crystalloid solutions directly into the vein to rehydrate the cat and maintain electrolyte balance.
treatments.notes: This step is essential for two reasons: 1) To compensate for dehydration caused by severe vomiting and diarrhea. 2) To stimulate diuresis (urination), which promotes the excretion of toxins and protects the kidneys, especially if hemolysis (breakdown of red blood cells) has occurred.Symptomatic Supportive Care (Medication)

treatments.name: Drug Therapy (Atropine, Anticonvulsants)
treatments.description: Using specific medications to treat life-threatening symptoms. Atropine may be administered to counteract cholinergic symptoms like a dangerously slow heart rate (bradycardia). Benzodiazepines or barbiturates may be used to control seizures.
treatments.notes: There is no specific antidote for solanine poisoning. Treatment focuses on managing severe neurological signs (tremors, seizures) and respiratory distress. Oxygen supplementation or mechanical ventilation may be required in critical cases.
